definitions.definition: A (software) distribution is a package or collection of software that is bundled together for easy installation and use.
Software distribution is the process of delivering software and it is the asset that contains the data used in the process.
A Linux distribution is an operating system made from a software collection that is based upon the Linux kernel and, often, a package management system.

notes.note: Key components of a Linux distribution include the Linux kernel, GNU tools and libraries, a package management system, and additional software applications.
Each distribution is tailored for specific use cases, such as personal computing, server management, or software development.

definitions.definition: The Linux kernel is the core component of a Linux operating system, managing system resources and communication between hardware and software.
Concurrency in operating systems refers to the capability of an OS to handle more than one task or process at the same time, thereby enhancing efficiency and responsiveness.
More than one program may run simultaneously on shared resources of the system, such as CPU, memory, and so on.
Concurrency in an operating system refers to the ability to execute multiple processes or threads simultaneously, improving resource utilization and system efficiency.

notes.note: Concurrency is often implemented through multi-threading and multi-processing techniques.
Good concurrency handling is crucial for deadlock situations, race conditions, and usually also for uninterrupted execution of tasks.

definitions.definition: A kernel is the core part of an operating system. It acts as a bridge between software applications and the hardware of a computer.

notes.note: It handles tasks like running programs, accessing files and connecting to devices like printers and keyboards

definitions.definition: An Operating System includes the kernel as its core, but also provides a user interface, file system management, network services and various utility applications that allow users to interact with the system
